ratings.comment: Nice guy, but completely disorganized. Sends out tons of emails because he does not like using a class portal, which can get frustrating. There are very few guidelines about what is expected of you and he tends to send out assignments at the last minute without much explanation. Avoid.

Easily the worst class I've taken in my collegiate career. Coming in, I knew that the online instruction was lax/lazy, but I bit the bullet in order to graduate on time. There are no good examples or set requirements on how to complete on the assignments. The feedback that you do get, doesn't help. AVOID THIS CLASS AT ALL COSTS!!!

The class was quite interesting though the assignments were vague, the syllabus essentially useless, and the help from the professor non-existent. For the third major assignment in the class, there was hardly any instruction on how to complete the assignment and when I contacted him for help in understanding it, his response was "good luck."

A really nice guy, and much more interesting lecturer than most-but he is one of the more frustrating professors you will have at times. In PS218 you have basically no homework except for 4 group projects and a paper.  he has a vested interest in his students but gives very little time on projects and little leeway as far as grading goes.

Very high quality professor, he knows about elections and voting behavior and explains things well although he goes off on tangents. Somewhat disorganized and slow to grade. Make sure you are really interested in the subject matter before taking a class with Franklin because he gets really in depth and the readings are dry, but you'll learn a lot.

Electoral System & Social Choice was a class that could have been insanely boring, but Franklin MADE it fun. Although he may seem unorganized, the man is a genius of political statistics (& a funny guy to boot). Readings are boring and so are the occasional lecture, but he includes students a lot and is very helpful. Do the readings & you'll b fine

Great professor whose genuine love for political science shows up in every class. This class was at 8am and somehow he kept me involved. The class is a lot different than others--you have oral interviews and have to write short insightful "nuggets" rather than having tests. He isn't easy, but he isn't unfair, either.

One of two people I've ever encountered that can make the presentation of rather grim and ostensibly boring public health statistics a laugh riot. If you're looking for a good stats course, take Intro to Political Numbers. It's challenging, but well worth it.
Hard, but quality. He's a great professor.
